edu.ncsu.csc.Galant.graph.component

Class Node

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.ncsu.csc.Galant.graph.component.GraphElement
      • edu.ncsu.csc.Galant.graph.component.Node
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<Node>

    public class Node
extends GraphElement
implements java.lang.Comparable<Node>
    Represents node entities as elements of a graph.
    Author:
    Michael Owoc, Ty Devries

      • travel

        public Node travel(Edge e)
        Returns the adjacent node along a given incident edge. If the edge is not incident to this node, then null is returned Compares the nodes of the edge to This and returns the other one. No issue on a self loop: will find that the first Node is This and return the other
        Parameters:
        e -

      • getPosition

        public java.awt.Point getPosition()
        The methods getPosition() and setPosition() are intended for use by the creator of an algorithm to, for example, exchange positions of nodes during sorting or a crossing minimization algorithm. Once setPosition() is invoked for a node it is no longer possible for the user to change the position of that node via mouse dragging.

      • getPosition

        public java.awt.Point getPosition(int state)

        public int getX()

      • setX

      • setY

        public void setY(int y)

      • getFixedPosition

        public java.awt.Point getFixedPosition()
        The fixed versions, getFixedPosition() and setFixedPosition() are used within the Galant software to access/modify positions of nodes during parsing of GraphML input, in response to mouse dragging, or when the force directed heuristic is applied to reposition nodes. During execution of an algorithm, a position set by the algorithm takes precedence, i.e., a node moved by the algorithm can no longer be moved via dragging. However, any node that is *not* moved by the algorithm *can* still be moved by the user. The main issue is that it is desirable not to have a state change when the position of a node is modified during editing.

      • setFixedPosition

        public void setFixedPosition(java.awt.Point position)

      • setFixedPosition

        public void setFixedPosition(int x,
                    int y)

      • getLatestValidState

        public NodeState getLatestValidState(int stateNumber)
        This method is vital for retrieving the most recent information about a node, where most recent is defined relative to a given time stamp, as defined by forward and backward stepping through the animation.
        Parameters:
        stateNumber - the numerical indicator (timestamp) of a state, usually the current one in the animation
        Returns:
        the latest instance of NodeState that was created before the given time stamp, or null if the node did not exist before the time stamp.
